title: Synthetic Recap
body:
HOUSTON (AP) – In the grand tapestry of the NBA, some performances are not merely games; they are declarations. On a night in 1997, inside the cacophony of The Summit, David Robinson delivered one for the ages, authoring a legendary chapter in San Antonio Spurs lore with a breathtaking 71-point spectacle to dismantrel the Houston Rockets, 115-101.

From the opening tip, Robinson was a study in unstoppable force. He wasn't just scoring; he was conducting a masterclass in the low post, facing up, and dominating the glass. The Rockets, a formidable opponent with the likes of Hakeem Olajuwon and Clyde Drexler, threw everything they had at the Admiral. It simply did not matter. Shot after shot fell with a ruthless, mechanical efficiency.

The stat line reads like a fiction: 71 points, a number that resonates among the league's all-time single-game greats. He hauled in 14 rebounds, a testament to his complete dominance on both ends. While the Rockets' stars fought valiantly—Olajuwon with 29 points and Drexler contributing 18—they were rendered spectators in Robinson's one-man showcase.

This was more than a road victory. It was an historic eruption, a performance so colossal it single-handedly lifted the Spurs over a Western Conference rival. On this night, Robinson wasn't just a star among stars; he was the sun around which the entire game orbited, leaving an indelible mark on the record books and securing his place in basketball immortality.
